subsection.title: Complex linear systems
subsection.p: Linear systems with complex coefficients behave exactly the same as systems with real coefficients.

example.title: Turning a complex linear system into an augmented complex matrix
example.p:
Consider the system
\begin{array}{rcrcr} (1 - \ci) x \amp - \amp 4 y \amp = \amp -3 + 9 \ci \\ (2 + \ci) x \amp + \amp (1 - 2 \ci) y \amp = \amp -5 \ci \end{array}.
As usual, we can represent this system as an augmented matrix, with one row per equation and one column per variable, with an extra augmented column for the constants on the right of the equals signs.

example.title: Reducing a complex augmented matrix
example.p: Here we will reduce the augmented matrix for the system from . There are always multiple ways to reduce a matrix, but, as usual, we are not interested in the most efficient way. Instead, we will demonstrate a systematic way to reduce while avoiding complicated calculations with complex numbers, especially division.

Rather than divide by a complex number to obtain a leading one in the top left, we start by using the complex conjugate to first convert the upper left entry to a real number. (For this particular matrix, we could achieve the same result by simply adding the second row to the first, but again we wish to demonstrate a systematic method in a simple example.)
\left[\begin{array}{cc|c} 1 - \ci \amp -4 \amp -3 + 9 \ci \\ 2 + \ci \amp 1 - 2 \ci \amp -5 \ci \end{array}\right] \begin{matrix} (1 + \ci) R_1 \\ \phantom{x} \end{matrix} \longrightarrow \left[\begin{array}{cc|c} 2 \amp -4 - 4 \ci \amp -12 + 6 \ci \\ 2 + \ci \amp 1 - 2 \ci \amp -5 \ci \end{array}\right]
Now we can easily obtain a leading one by dividing by a real number.
\left[\begin{array}{cc|c} 2 \amp -4 - 4 \ci \amp -12 + 6 \ci \\ 2 + \ci \amp 1 - 2 \ci \amp -5 \ci \end{array}\right] \begin{matrix} \frac{1}{2} R_1 \\ \phantom{x} \end{matrix} \longrightarrow \left[\begin{array}{cc|c} 1 \amp -2 - 2 \ci \amp -6 + 3 \ci \\ 2 + \ci \amp 1 - 2 \ci \amp -5 \ci \end{array}\right]
Note that these first two operations together are equivalent to dividing the first row by 1 - \ci.

example.title: Solving a complex linear system
example.p: To solve a complex linear system we proceed just as in the real case, by reducing, assigning parameters (if necessary), and solving for each variable either exactly or in terms of the assigned parameters. The only difference is that parameters should be allowed to take on every possible complex value, instead of just every possible real value.

Each different choice of a pair of complex values for parameters s and t leads to a different specific solution. With a homogeneous system, we still always have the trivial solution, x_1 = x_2 = x_3 = x_4 = 0, in this case associated to choice s = 0, t = 0.

We also have two specific solutions attached to each parameter, one from choosing s = 1, t = 0 to obtain solution
x_1 \amp = -2 - 3 \ci, \amp x_2 \amp = 1, \amp x_3 \amp = 0, \amp x_4 \amp = 0,
and another from choosing s = 0, t = 1 to obtain solution
x_1 \amp = -1 + \ci, \amp x_2 \amp = 0, \amp x_3 \amp = 2 - 2 \ci, \amp x_4 \amp = 1.

As mentioned at the beginning of this example, parameters s and t can take on any complex values. For example, choosing s = 7 \ci and t = 5 - 4 \ci yields particular solution
x_1 \amp = 20 - 5 \ci, \amp x_2 \amp = 7 \ci, \amp x_3 \amp = 2 - 18 \ci, \amp x_4 \amp = 5 - 4 \ci.

introduction.p: The basic operations of matrix addition, subtraction, multiplication, and scalar multiplication all work the same for matrices with complex entries as for matrices with real entries, except that the computations become a little more involved.
We will concentrate here on a few examples involving inverses, the determinant, and the new conjugate and complex adjoint operations.

example.title: Using the 2 \times 2 inversion formula
example.p: also applies to complex matrices.

example.title: Using the row reduction method to compute an inverse
Complex determinant by cofactor expansion
example.p:
Let's compute the determinant of the complex matrix
B = \begin{bmatrix} 1 + \ci \amp 2 \amp - 3\ci \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp -2 - 4 \ci \\ \ci \amp 0 \amp 1 + \ci \end{bmatrix}.
Matrix B is one row operation away from the matrix A from . Since we found A to be invertible, B should be invertible as well, and so we expect to find \det B to be nonzero.

example.title: The conjugate of a matrix
example.p:
Let's compute the conjugate of the matrix from :
A \amp = \begin{bmatrix} 1 + \ci \amp 0 \amp 2 + \ci \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp -2 - 4 \ci \\ \ci \amp 0 \amp 1 + \ci \end{bmatrix}, \amp \cconj{A} \amp = \begin{bmatrix} 1 - \ci \amp 0 \amp 2 - \ci \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp -2 + 4 \ci \\ -\ci \amp 0 \amp 1 - \ci \end{bmatrix}.
Notice that the purely real entries do not change, while the purely imaginary entries become negative.

While we're at it, let's compute the conjugate of the inverse of A:
\inv{A} \amp = \begin{bmatrix} 1 + \ci \amp 0 \amp -2 - \ci \\ 2 - \ci \amp \frac{1}{2} \amp -1 + 3 \ci \\ -\ci \amp 0 \amp 1 + \ci \end{bmatrix}, \amp \lcconj{\inv{A}} \amp = \begin{bmatrix} 1 - \ci \amp 0 \amp -2 + \ci \\ 2 + \ci \amp \frac{1}{2} \amp -1 - 3 \ci \\ \ci \amp 0 \amp 1 - \ci \end{bmatrix}.
What do you think will happen if we multiply \cconj{A} and \lcconj{\inv{A}} together?
\cconj{A} \lcconj{\inv{A}} \amp = \begin{bmatrix} 1 - \ci \amp 0 \amp 2 - \ci \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp -2 + 4 \ci \\ -\ci \amp 0 \amp 1 - \ci \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 - \ci \amp 0 \amp -2 + \ci \\ 2 + \ci \amp \frac{1}{2} \amp -1 - 3 \ci \\ \ci \amp 0 \amp 1 - \ci \end{bmatrix}
\amp = \begin{bmatrix} (1 - \ci)^2 + (2 - \ci) \cdot \ci \amp 0 \amp (1 - \ci) (-2 + \ci) + (2 - \ci) (1 - \ci) \\ 2 (2 + \ci) + (-2 + 4 \ci) \cdot \ci \amp 2 \cdot \frac{1}{2} \amp 2 (-1 - 3 \ci) + (-2 + 4 \ci) (1 - \ci) \\ -\ci (1 - \ci) + (1 - \ci) \cdot \ci \amp 0 \amp -\ci (-2 + \ci) + (1 - \ci)^2 \end{bmatrix}
\amp = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{bmatrix}.
Surprised? With the above calculation, we have verified (for this example) that
\inv{(\cconj{A})} = \lcconj{\inv{A}} . In
we will record that this formula holds in general.

example.title: The complex adjoint of a matrix
example.p:
Continuing , we have
A \amp = \begin{bmatrix} 1 + \ci \amp 0 \amp 2 + \ci \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp -2 - 4 \ci \\ \ci \amp 0 \amp 1 + \ci \end{bmatrix}, \amp \adjoint{A} \amp = \begin{bmatrix} 1 - \ci \amp 0 \amp -\ci \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 2 - \ci \amp -2 + 4 \ci \amp 1 - \ci \end{bmatrix}.
The adjoint \adjoint{A} is computed by taking the transpose of the conjugate \cconj{A}. The pattern between A and \adjoint{A} is as follows: each entry along the main diagonal is conjugated, and each off-diagonal entry is both conjugated and reflected to its symmetric position on the other side of the main diagonal.

Similarly to , you can compute the product \adjoint{A} \adjoint{\bigl(\inv{A}\bigr)} if you like, but just taking the transpose of both sides of formula
and using
on the left will lead to the formula \inv{\bigl(\adjoint{A}\bigr)} = \adjoint{\bigl(\inv{A}\bigr)} .

example.title: Self-adjoint matrices
example.p: What is the pattern that worked in A but not in B? First, every entry along the main diagonal in A is real, and so is equal to its own conjugate. Which is important, because entries along the diagonal do not change when taking the transpose. However, B has an entry along the main diagonal that is not real. Second, every entry not along the main diagonal in A is equal to the conjugate of the entry in the symmetric position on the other side of the main diagonal. However, in B the (1,3) and (3,1) entries are both equal to 1 + \ci, and so are not equal to the conjugate of each other.
